heading: stocks retreat after late rally
subheading: the market closed down slightly tuesday after a late surge spurred by speculation that interest rates would not be raised.
author: reuters
text: stocks crawled back into the minus column monday after the market was unable to hold onto a big rally that was spurred by news the us economy may be slowing, perhaps enough to keep the federal reserve from raising interest rates again. based on early and unofficial close, the dow jones industrial average ended down 9.19 points, or 0.09 percent, at 10,645.96 after giving up an early gain of nearly 140 points.in the broader market, declining issues led advances 17 to 12 on moderate volume of 627 million shares on the new york stock exchange.the technology-heavy nasdaq composite index fell 14.85 points, or 0.56 percent, at 2,623.64.in the bond market, the 30-year us treasury bond's price was off 1/8 of a point and the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 6.12 percent from 6.11 percent on friday.the stock market's rally was ignited by the national association of purchasing management's report that the nation's manufacturing sector grew at a slower-than-expected pace in july.the july napm index came in at 53.4, which was less than the 56.1 reading economists polled by reuters had forecast.wall street viewed the report as positive in the wake of federal reserve chairman alan greenspan's warning that the central bank may raise interest rates again if the economy does not slow or inflation picks up, analysts said."basically, at this point, the economy is slowing," said peter cardillo, director of research, westfalia investments."that should give the bond some sign of relief," which also is "good for stocks."the concern over inflation and a tighter monetary policy had contributed to the selloff that wiped out nearly 600 points in the dow over the last two weeks.general housewares soared 7 to 27-1/2. the company agreed to be acquired by corning consumer products, a unit of privately owned borden inc., for us$145 million. holders of general housewares would receive $28.75 per share in cash.sears, roebuck & co rose 1-1/16 to 41-9/16. the giant retailer said it will cut up to 1,400 jobs at its suburban chicago headquarters by oct. 31 in an effort to control expenses. the company has about 6,800 workers at the headquarters location.copyright
